text: "Then it was not Arthur who took them?"
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "I told you yesterday, and I repeat to-day, that it was not."
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "You are sure of it! Then let us hurry to him at once to let him
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: know that the truth is known."
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "He knows it already. When I had cleared it all up I had an
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: lips."
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "For heaven's sake, tell me, then, what is this extraordinary
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: mystery!"
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "I will do so, and I will show you the steps by which I reached
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: it. And let me say to you, first, that which it is hardest for me
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: to say and for you to hear: there has been an understanding
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: between Sir George Burnwell and your niece Mary. They have now
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: fled together."
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "My Mary? Impossible!"
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "It is unfortunately more than possible; it is certain. Neither
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: you nor your son knew the true character of this man when you
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: admitted him into your family circle. He is one of the most
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: dangerous men in England--a ruined gambler, an absolutely
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: desperate villain, a man without heart or conscience. Your niece
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: knew nothing of such men. When he breathed his vows to her, as he
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: had done to a hundred before her, she flattered herself that she
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: alone had touched his heart. The devil knows best what he said,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: but at least she became his tool and was in the habit of seeing
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: him nearly every evening."
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "I cannot, and I will not, believe it!" cried the banker with an
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: ashen face.
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "I will tell you, then, what occurred in your house last night.
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: Your niece, when you had, as she thought, gone to your room,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: slipped down and talked to her lover through the window which
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: leads into the stable lane. His footmarks had pressed right
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: through the snow, so long had he stood there. She told him of the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: coronet. His wicked lust for gold kindled at the news, and he
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: bent her to his will. I have no doubt that she loved you, but
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: there are women in whom the love of a lover extinguishes all
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: other loves, and I think that she must have been one. She had
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: hardly listened to his instructions when she saw you coming
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: downstairs, on which she closed the window rapidly and told you
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: about one of the servants' escapade with her wooden-legged lover,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: which was all perfectly true.
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "Your boy, Arthur, went to bed after his interview with you but
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: he slept badly on account of his uneasiness about his club debts.
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: In the middle of the night he heard a soft tread pass his door,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: so he rose and, looking out, was surprised to see his cousin
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: walking very stealthily along the passage until she disappeared
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: into your dressing-room. Petrified with astonishment, the lad
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: slipped on some clothes and waited there in the dark to see what
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: would come of this strange affair. Presently she emerged from the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: room again, and in the light of the passage-lamp your son saw
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: that she carried the precious coronet in her hands. She passed
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: down the stairs, and he, thrilling with horror, ran along and
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: slipped behind the curtain near your door, whence he could see
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: what passed in the hall beneath. He saw her stealthily open the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: window, hand out the coronet to someone in the gloom, and then
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: closing it once more hurry back to her room, passing quite close
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: to where he stood hid behind the curtain.
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "As long as she was on the scene he could not take any action
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: without a horrible exposure of the woman whom he loved. But the

story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: this would be for you, and how all-important it was to set it
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: right. He rushed down, just as he was, in his bare feet, opened
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: the window, sprang out into the snow, and ran down the lane,

story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: to preserve impressions. I passed along the tradesmen's path, but
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: found it all trampled down and indistinguishable. Just beyond it,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: however, at the far side of the kitchen door, a woman had stood
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: and talked with a man, whose round impressions on one side showed
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: that he had a wooden leg. I could even tell that they had been
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: disturbed, for the woman had run back swiftly to the door, as was
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: shown by the deep toe and light heel marks, while Wooden-leg had
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: waited a little, and then had gone away. I thought at the time
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: that this might be the maid and her sweetheart, of whom you had
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: already spoken to me, and inquiry showed it was so. I passed
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: round the garden without seeing anything more than random tracks,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: which I took to be the police; but when I got into the stable
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: lane a very long and complex story was written in the snow in
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: front of me.
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "There was a double line of tracks of a booted man, and a second
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: double line which I saw with delight belonged to a man with naked
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: feet. I was at once convinced from what you had told me that the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: latter was your son. The first had walked both ways, but the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: other had run swiftly, and as his tread was marked in places over
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: the depression of the boot, it was obvious that he had passed
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: after the other. I followed them up and found they led to the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: hall window, where Boots had worn all the snow away while
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: waiting. Then I walked to the other end, which was a hundred
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: yards or more down the lane. I saw where Boots had faced round,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: where the snow was cut up as though there had been a struggle,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: and, finally, where a few drops of blood had fallen, to show me
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: that I was not mistaken. Boots had then run down the lane, and
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: another little smudge of blood showed that it was he who had been
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: hurt. When he came to the highroad at the other end, I found that
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: the pavement had been cleared, so there was an end to that clue.
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "On entering the house, however, I examined, as you remember, the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: sill and framework of the hall window with my lens, and I could
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: at once see that someone had passed out. I could distinguish the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: outline of an instep where the wet foot had been placed in coming
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: in. I was then beginning to be able to form an opinion as to what
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: had occurred. A man had waited outside the window; someone had
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: brought the gems; the deed had been overseen by your son; he had
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: pursued the thief; had struggled with him; they had each tugged
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: at the coronet, their united strength causing injuries which
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: neither alone could have effected. He had returned with the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: prize, but had left a fragment in the grasp of his opponent. So
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: far I was clear. The question now was, who was the man and who
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: was it brought him the coronet?
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "It is an old maxim of mine that when you have excluded the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: truth. Now, I knew that it was not you who had brought it down,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: so there only remained your niece and the maids. But if it were
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: the maids, why should your son allow himself to be accused in
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: their place? There could be no possible reason. As he loved his
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: cousin, however, there was an excellent explanation why he should
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: retain her secret--the more so as the secret was a disgraceful
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: one. When I remembered that you had seen her at that window, and
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: how she had fainted on seeing the coronet again, my conjecture
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: became a certainty.
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "And who could it be who was her confederate? A lover evidently,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: for who else could outweigh the love and gratitude which she must
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: feel to you? I knew that you went out little, and that your
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: circle of friends was a very limited one. But among them was Sir
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: George Burnwell. I had heard of him before as being a man of evil
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: reputation among women. It must have been he who wore those boots
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: and retained the missing gems. Even though he knew that Arthur
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: had discovered him, he might still flatter himself that he was
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: safe, for the lad could not say a word without compromising his
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: own family.
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "Well, your own good sense will suggest what measures I took
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: next. I went in the shape of a loafer to Sir George's house,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: managed to pick up an acquaintance with his valet, learned that
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: his master had cut his head the night before, and, finally, at
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: the expense of six shillings, made all sure by buying a pair of
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: his cast-off shoes. With these I journeyed down to Streatham and
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: saw that they exactly fitted the tracks."
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "I saw an ill-dressed vagabond in the lane yesterday evening,"
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: said Mr. Holder.
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "Precisely. It was I. I found that I had my man, so I came home
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: and changed my clothes. It was a delicate part which I had to
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: play then, for I saw that a prosecution must be avoided to avert
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: scandal, and I knew that so astute a villain would see that our
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: hands were tied in the matter. I went and saw him. At first, of
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: course, he denied everything. But when I gave him every
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: particular that had occurred, he tried to bluster and took down a
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: life-preserver from the wall. I knew my man, however, and I
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: clapped a pistol to his head before he could strike. Then he
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: became a little more reasonable. I told him that we would give
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: him a price for the stones he held--1000 pounds apiece. That
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: brought out the first signs of grief that he had shown. 'Why,
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: dash it all!' said he, 'I've let them go at six hundred for the
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: three!' I soon managed to get the address of the receiver who had
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: them, on promising him that there would be no prosecution. Off I
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: set to him, and after much chaffering I got our stones at 1000
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: pounds apiece. Then I looked in upon your son, told him that all
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: was right, and eventually got to my bed about two o'clock, after
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: what I may call a really hard day's work."
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "A day which has saved England from a great public scandal," said
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: the banker, rising. "Sir, I cannot find words to thank you, but
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: you shall not find me ungrateful for what you have done. Your
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: have done him. As to what you tell me of poor Mary, it goes to my
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: very heart. Not even your skill can inform me where she is now."
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET
XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: "I think that we may safely say," returned Holmes, "that she is
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: wherever Sir George Burnwell is. It is equally certain, too, that
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: whatever her sins are, they will soon receive a more than
story: XI. THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

text: my powers to determine. As to Holmes, I observed that he sat
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: frequently for half an hour on end, with knitted brows and an
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: abstracted air, but he swept the matter away with a wave of his
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: hand when I mentioned it. "Data! data! data!" he cried
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: impatiently. "I can't make bricks without clay." And yet he would
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: always wind up by muttering that no sister of his should ever
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: have accepted such a situation.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: The telegram which we eventually received came late one night
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: just as I was thinking of turning in and Holmes was settling down
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: to one of those all-night chemical researches which he frequently
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: indulged in, when I would leave him stooping over a retort and a
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: test-tube at night and find him in the same position when I came
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: down to breakfast in the morning. He opened the yellow envelope,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and then, glancing at the message, threw it across to me.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Just look up the trains in Bradshaw," said he, and turned back
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: to his chemical studies.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: The summons was a brief and urgent one.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Please be at the Black Swan Hotel at Winchester at midday
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: to-morrow," it said. "Do come! I am at my wit's end.  HUNTER."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Will you come with me?" asked Holmes, glancing up.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I should wish to."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Just look it up, then."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "There is a train at half-past nine," said I, glancing over my
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Bradshaw. "It is due at Winchester at 11:30."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "That will do very nicely. Then perhaps I had better postpone my
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: analysis of the acetones, as we may need to be at our best in the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: morning."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: By eleven o'clock the next day we were well upon our way to the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: old English capital. Holmes had been buried in the morning papers
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: all the way down, but after we had passed the Hampshire border he
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: threw them down and began to admire the scenery. It was an ideal
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: spring day, a light blue sky, flecked with little fleecy white
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: clouds drifting across from west to east. The sun was shining
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: very brightly, and yet there was an exhilarating nip in the air,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: which set an edge to a man's energy. All over the countryside,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: away to the rolling hills around Aldershot, the little red and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: grey roofs of the farm-steadings peeped out from amid the light
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: green of the new foliage.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Are they not fresh and beautiful?" I cried with all the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: enthusiasm of a man fresh from the fogs of Baker Street.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: But Holmes shook his head gravely.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Do you know, Watson," said he, "that it is one of the curses of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: a mind with a turn like mine that I must look at everything with
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: reference to my own special subject. You look at these scattered
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: houses, and you are impressed by their beauty. I look at them,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and the only thought which comes to me is a feeling of their
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: isolation and of the impunity with which crime may be committed
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: there."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Good heavens!" I cried. "Who would associate crime with these
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: dear old homesteads?"
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "They always fill me with a certain horror. It is my belief,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Watson, founded upon my experience, that the lowest and vilest
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: alleys in London do not present a more dreadful record of sin
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: than does the smiling and beautiful countryside."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "You horrify me!"
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "But the reason is very obvious. The pressure of public opinion
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: can do in the town what the law cannot accomplish. There is no
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: lane so vile that the scream of a tortured child, or the thud of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: a drunkard's blow, does not beget sympathy and indignation among
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the neighbours, and then the whole machinery of justice is ever
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: so close that a word of complaint can set it going, and there is
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: but a step between the crime and the dock. But look at these
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: lonely houses, each in its own fields, filled for the most part
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: with poor ignorant folk who know little of the law. Think of the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: deeds of hellish cruelty, the hidden wickedness which may go on,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: year in, year out, in such places, and none the wiser. Had this
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: lady who appeals to us for help gone to live in Winchester, I
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: should never have had a fear for her. It is the five miles of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: country which makes the danger. Still, it is clear that she is
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: not personally threatened."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "No. If she can come to Winchester to meet us she can get away."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Quite so. She has her freedom."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "What CAN be the matter, then? Can you suggest no explanation?"
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I have devised seven separate explanations, each of which would
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: cover the facts as far as we know them. But which of these is
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: correct can only be determined by the fresh information which we
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: shall no doubt find waiting for us. Well, there is the tower of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the cathedral, and we shall soon learn all that Miss Hunter has
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: to tell."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: The Black Swan is an inn of repute in the High Street, at no
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: distance from the station, and there we found the young lady
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: waiting for us. She had engaged a sitting-room, and our lunch
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: awaited us upon the table.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I am so delighted that you have come," she said earnestly. "It
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: is so very kind of you both; but indeed I do not know what I
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: should do. Your advice will be altogether invaluable to me."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Pray tell us what has happened to you."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I will do so, and I must be quick, for I have promised Mr.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Rucastle to be back before three. I got his leave to come into
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: town this morning, though he little knew for what purpose."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Let us have everything in its due order." Holmes thrust his long
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: thin legs out towards the fire and composed himself to listen.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "In the first place, I may say that I have met, on the whole,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: with no actual ill-treatment from Mr. and Mrs. Rucastle. It is
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: only fair to them to say that. But I cannot understand them, and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: I am not easy in my mind about them."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "What can you not understand?"
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Their reasons for their conduct. But you shall have it all just
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: as it occurred. When I came down, Mr. Rucastle met me here and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: drove me in his dog-cart to the Copper Beeches. It is, as he
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: said, beautifully situated, but it is not beautiful in itself,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: for it is a large square block of a house, whitewashed, but all
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: stained and streaked with damp and bad weather. There are grounds
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: round it, woods on three sides, and on the fourth a field which
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: slopes down to the Southampton highroad, which curves past about
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: a hundred yards from the front door. This ground in front belongs
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: to the house, but the woods all round are part of Lord
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Southerton's preserves. A clump of copper beeches immediately in
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: front of the hall door has given its name to the place.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I was driven over by my employer, who was as amiable as ever,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and was introduced by him that evening to his wife and the child.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: There was no truth, Mr. Holmes, in the conjecture which seemed to
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: us to be probable in your rooms at Baker Street. Mrs. Rucastle is
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: not mad. I found her to be a silent, pale-faced woman, much
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: younger than her husband, not more than thirty, I should think,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: while he can hardly be less than forty-five. From their
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: conversation I have gathered that they have been married about
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: seven years, that he was a widower, and that his only child by
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the first wife was the daughter who has gone to Philadelphia. Mr.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Rucastle told me in private that the reason why she had left them
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: was that she had an unreasoning aversion to her stepmother. As
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the daughter could not have been less than twenty, I can quite
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: imagine that her position must have been uncomfortable with her
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: father's young wife.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Mrs. Rucastle seemed to me to be colourless in mind as well as
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: in feature. She impressed me neither favourably nor the reverse.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: She was a nonentity. It was easy to see that she was passionately
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: devoted both to her husband and to her little son. Her light grey
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: eyes wandered continually from one to the other, noting every
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: little want and forestalling it if possible. He was kind to her
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: also in his bluff, boisterous fashion, and on the whole they
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: seemed to be a happy couple. And yet she had some secret sorrow,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: this woman. She would often be lost in deep thought, with the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: saddest look upon her face. More than once I have surprised her
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: in tears. I have thought sometimes that it was the disposition of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: her child which weighed upon her mind, for I have never met so
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: utterly spoiled and so ill-natured a little creature. He is small
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: for his age, with a head which is quite disproportionately large.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: His whole life appears to be spent in an alternation between
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: savage fits of passion and gloomy intervals of sulking. Giving
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: pain to any creature weaker than himself seems to be his one idea
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: of amusement, and he shows quite remarkable talent in planning
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the capture of mice, little birds, and insects. But I would
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: rather not talk about the creature, Mr. Holmes, and, indeed, he
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: has little to do with my story."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I am glad of all details," remarked my friend, "whether they
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: seem to you to be relevant or not."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I shall try not to miss anything of importance. The one
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: unpleasant thing about the house, which struck me at once, was
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the appearance and conduct of the servants. There are only two, a
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: man and his wife. Toller, for that is his name, is a rough,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: uncouth man, with grizzled hair and whiskers, and a perpetual
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: smell of drink. Twice since I have been with them he has been
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: quite drunk, and yet Mr. Rucastle seemed to take no notice of it.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: His wife is a very tall and strong woman with a sour face, as
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: silent as Mrs. Rucastle and much less amiable. They are a most
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: unpleasant couple, but fortunately I spend most of my time in the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: nursery and my own room, which are next to each other in one
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: corner of the building.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "For two days after my arrival at the Copper Beeches my life was
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: very quiet; on the third, Mrs. Rucastle came down just after
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: breakfast and whispered something to her husband.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'Oh, yes,' said he, turning to me, 'we are very much obliged to
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: you, Miss Hunter, for falling in with our whims so far as to cut
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: your hair. I assure you that it has not detracted in the tiniest
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: iota from your appearance. We shall now see how the electric-blue
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: dress will become you. You will find it laid out upon the bed in
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: your room, and if you would be so good as to put it on we should
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: both be extremely obliged.'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "The dress which I found waiting for me was of a peculiar shade
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: of blue. It was of excellent material, a sort of beige, but it
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: bore unmistakable signs of having been worn before. It could not
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: have been a better fit if I had been measured for it. Both Mr.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and Mrs. Rucastle expressed a delight at the look of it, which
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: seemed quite exaggerated in its vehemence. They were waiting for
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: me in the drawing-room, which is a very large room, stretching
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: along the entire front of the house, with three long windows
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: reaching down to the floor. A chair had been placed close to the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: central window, with its back turned towards it. In this I was
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: asked to sit, and then Mr. Rucastle, walking up and down on the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: other side of the room, began to tell me a series of the funniest
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: stories that I have ever listened to. You cannot imagine how
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: comical he was, and I laughed until I was quite weary. Mrs.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Rucastle, however, who has evidently no sense of humour, never so
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: much as smiled, but sat with her hands in her lap, and a sad,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: anxious look upon her face. After an hour or so, Mr. Rucastle
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: suddenly remarked that it was time to commence the duties of the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: day, and that I might change my dress and go to little Edward in
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the nursery.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Two days later this same performance was gone through under
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: exactly similar circumstances. Again I changed my dress, again I
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: sat in the window, and again I laughed very heartily at the funny
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: stories of which my employer had an immense repertoire, and which
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: he told inimitably. Then he handed me a yellow-backed novel, and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: moving my chair a little sideways, that my own shadow might not
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: fall upon the page, he begged me to read aloud to him. I read for
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: about ten minutes, beginning in the heart of a chapter, and then
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: suddenly, in the middle of a sentence, he ordered me to cease and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: to change my dress.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "You can easily imagine, Mr. Holmes, how curious I became as to
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: what the meaning of this extraordinary performance could possibly
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: be. They were always very careful, I observed, to turn my face
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: away from the window, so that I became consumed with the desire
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: to see what was going on behind my back. At first it seemed to be
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: impossible, but I soon devised a means. My hand-mirror had been
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: broken, so a happy thought seized me, and I concealed a piece of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the glass in my handkerchief. On the next occasion, in the midst
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: of my laughter, I put my handkerchief up to my eyes, and was able
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: with a little management to see all that there was behind me. I
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: confess that I was disappointed. There was nothing. At least that
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: was my first impression. At the second glance, however, I

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'No, I know no one in these parts.'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I did as I was told, and at the same instant Mrs. Rucastle drew
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: down the blind. That was a week ago, and from that time I have
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Pray continue," said Holmes. "Your narrative promises to be a
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: most interesting one."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "You will find it rather disconnected, I fear, and there may
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: prove to be little relation between the different incidents of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: which I speak. On the very first day that I was at the Copper
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Beeches, Mr. Rucastle took me to a small outhouse which stands
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: near the kitchen door. As we approached it I heard the sharp
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: rattling of a chain, and the sound as of a large animal moving
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: about.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'Look in here!' said Mr. Rucastle, showing me a slit between two
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: planks. 'Is he not a beauty?'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I looked through and was conscious of two glowing eyes, and of a
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: vague figure huddled up in the darkness.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'Don't be frightened,' said my employer, laughing at the start
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: which I had given. 'It's only Carlo, my mastiff. I call him mine,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: but really old Toller, my groom, is the only man who can do
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: anything with him. We feed him once a day, and not too much then,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: so that he is always as keen as mustard. Toller lets him loose
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: every night, and God help the trespasser whom he lays his fangs
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: upon. For goodness' sake don't you ever on any pretext set your
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: foot over the threshold at night, for it's as much as your life
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: is worth.'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "The warning was no idle one, for two nights later I happened to
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: look out of my bedroom window about two o'clock in the morning.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: It was a beautiful moonlight night, and the lawn in front of the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: house was silvered over and almost as bright as day. I was
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: standing, rapt in the peaceful beauty of the scene, when I was
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: aware that something was moving under the shadow of the copper
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: beeches. As it emerged into the moonshine I saw what it was. It
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: was a giant dog, as large as a calf, tawny tinted, with hanging
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: jowl, black muzzle, and huge projecting bones. It walked slowly
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: across the lawn and vanished into the shadow upon the other side.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: That dreadful sentinel sent a chill to my heart which I do not
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: think that any burglar could have done.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "And now I have a very strange experience to tell you. I had, as
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: you know, cut off my hair in London, and I had placed it in a
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: great coil at the bottom of my trunk. One evening, after the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: child was in bed, I began to amuse myself by examining the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: furniture of my room and by rearranging my own little things.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: There was an old chest of drawers in the room, the two upper ones
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: empty and open, the lower one locked. I had filled the first two
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: with my linen, and as I had still much to pack away I was
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: naturally annoyed at not having the use of the third drawer. It
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: struck me that it might have been fastened by a mere oversight,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: so I took out my bunch of keys and tried to open it. The very
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: first key fitted to perfection, and I drew the drawer open. There
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: was only one thing in it, but I am sure that you would never
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: guess what it was. It was my coil of hair.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I took it up and examined it. It was of the same peculiar tint,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and the same thickness. But then the impossibility of the thing
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: obtruded itself upon me. How could my hair have been locked in
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the drawer? With trembling hands I undid my trunk, turned out the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: contents, and drew from the bottom my own hair. I laid the two
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: tresses together, and I assure you that they were identical. Was
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: it not extraordinary? Puzzle as I would, I could make nothing at
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: all of what it meant. I returned the strange hair to the drawer,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and I said nothing of the matter to the Rucastles as I felt that
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: I had put myself in the wrong by opening a drawer which they had
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: locked.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I am naturally observant, as you may have remarked, Mr. Holmes,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and I soon had a pretty good plan of the whole house in my head.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: There was one wing, however, which appeared not to be inhabited
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: at all. A door which faced that which led into the quarters of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the Tollers opened into this suite, but it was invariably locked.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: One day, however, as I ascended the stair, I met Mr. Rucastle
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: coming out through this door, his keys in his hand, and a look on
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: his face which made him a very different person to the round,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: jovial man to whom I was accustomed. His cheeks were red, his
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: brow was all crinkled with anger, and the veins stood out at his
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: temples with passion. He locked the door and hurried past me
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: without a word or a look.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "This aroused my curiosity, so when I went out for a walk in the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: grounds with my charge, I strolled round to the side from which I
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: could see the windows of this part of the house. There were four
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: of them in a row, three of which were simply dirty, while the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: fourth was shuttered up. They were evidently all deserted. As I
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: strolled up and down, glancing at them occasionally, Mr. Rucastle
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: came out to me, looking as merry and jovial as ever.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'Ah!' said he, 'you must not think me rude if I passed you
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: without a word, my dear young lady. I was preoccupied with
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: business matters.'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I assured him that I was not offended. 'By the way,' said I,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: 'you seem to have quite a suite of spare rooms up there, and one
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: of them has the shutters up.'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "He looked surprised and, as it seemed to me, a little startled
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: at my remark.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'Photography is one of my hobbies,' said he. 'I have made my
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: dark room up there. But, dear me! what an observant young lady we
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: have come upon. Who would have believed it? Who would have ever
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: believed it?' He spoke in a jesting tone, but there was no jest
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: in his eyes as he looked at me. I read suspicion there and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: annoyance, but no jest.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Well, Mr. Holmes, from the moment that I understood that there
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: was something about that suite of rooms which I was not to know,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: I was all on fire to go over them. It was not mere curiosity,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: though I have my share of that. It was more a feeling of duty--a
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: feeling that some good might come from my penetrating to this
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: place. They talk of woman's instinct; perhaps it was woman's
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: instinct which gave me that feeling. At any rate, it was there,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and I was keenly on the lookout for any chance to pass the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: forbidden door.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "It was only yesterday that the chance came. I may tell you that,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: besides Mr. Rucastle, both Toller and his wife find something to
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: do in these deserted rooms, and I once saw him carrying a large
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: black linen bag with him through the door. Recently he has been
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: drinking hard, and yesterday evening he was very drunk; and when
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: I came upstairs there was the key in the door. I have no doubt at
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: all that he had left it there. Mr. and Mrs. Rucastle were both
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: downstairs, and the child was with them, so that I had an
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: admirable opportunity. I turned the key gently in the lock,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: opened the door, and slipped through.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "There was a little passage in front of me, unpapered and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: uncarpeted, which turned at a right angle at the farther end.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Round this corner were three doors in a line, the first and third
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: of which were open. They each led into an empty room, dusty and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: cheerless, with two windows in the one and one in the other, so
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: thick with dirt that the evening light glimmered dimly through
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: them. The centre door was closed, and across the outside of it
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: had been fastened one of the broad bars of an iron bed, padlocked
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: at one end to a ring in the wall, and fastened at the other with
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: stout cord. The door itself was locked as well, and the key was
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: not there. This barricaded door corresponded clearly with the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: shuttered window outside, and yet I could see by the glimmer from
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: beneath it that the room was not in darkness. Evidently there was
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: a skylight which let in light from above. As I stood in the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: passage gazing at the sinister door and wondering what secret it
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: might veil, I suddenly heard the sound of steps within the room
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and saw a shadow pass backward and forward against the little
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: slit of dim light which shone out from under the door. A mad,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: unreasoning terror rose up in me at the sight, Mr. Holmes. My
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: overstrung nerves failed me suddenly, and I turned and ran--ran
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: as though some dreadful hand were behind me clutching at the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: skirt of my dress. I rushed down the passage, through the door,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and straight into the arms of Mr. Rucastle, who was waiting
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: outside.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'So,' said he, smiling, 'it was you, then. I thought that it
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: must be when I saw the door open.'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'Oh, I am so frightened!' I panted.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'My dear young lady! my dear young lady!'--you cannot think how
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: caressing and soothing his manner was--'and what has frightened
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: you, my dear young lady?'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "But his voice was just a little too coaxing. He overdid it. I
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: was keenly on my guard against him.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'I was foolish enough to go into the empty wing,' I answered.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: 'But it is so lonely and eerie in this dim light that I was
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: frightened and ran out again. Oh, it is so dreadfully still in
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: there!'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'Only that?' said he, looking at me keenly.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'Why, what did you think?' I asked.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'Why do you think that I lock this door?'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'I am sure that I do not know.'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "'I am sure if I had known--'
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: that threshold again'--here in an instant the smile hardened into
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I was so terrified that I do not know what I did. I suppose that
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Yes."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Yes, the wine-cellar."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "You seem to me to have acted all through this matter like a very
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: brave and sensible girl, Miss Hunter. Do you think that you could
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: perform one more feat? I should not ask it of you if I did not
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: think you a quite exceptional woman."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I will try. What is it?"
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "We shall be at the Copper Beeches by seven o'clock, my friend
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: and I. The Rucastles will be gone by that time, and Toller will,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: we hope, be incapable. There only remains Mrs. Toller, who might

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: matters immensely."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I will do it."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Excellent! We shall then look thoroughly into the affair. Of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: course there is only one feasible explanation. You have been
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: brought there to personate someone, and the real person is
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: imprisoned in this chamber. That is obvious. As to who this
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: prisoner is, I have no doubt that it is the daughter, Miss Alice
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Rucastle, if I remember right, who was said to have gone to
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: America. You were chosen, doubtless, as resembling her in height,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: figure, and the colour of your hair. Hers had been cut off, very
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: possibly in some illness through which she has passed, and so, of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: course, yours had to be sacrificed also. By a curious chance you
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: came upon her tresses. The man in the road was undoubtedly some
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: friend of hers--possibly her fiance--and no doubt, as you wore
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the girl's dress and were so like her, he was convinced from your
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: laughter, whenever he saw you, and afterwards from your gesture,
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: that Miss Rucastle was perfectly happy, and that she no longer
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: desired his attentions. The dog is let loose at night to prevent
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: him from endeavouring to communicate with her. So much is fairly
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: clear. The most serious point in the case is the disposition of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: the child."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "What on earth has that to do with it?" I ejaculated.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "My dear Watson, you as a medical man are continually gaining
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: light as to the tendencies of a child by the study of the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: parents. Don't you see that the converse is equally valid. I have
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: frequently gained my first real insight into the character of
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: parents by studying their children. This child's disposition is
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: abnormally cruel, merely for cruelty's sake, and whether he
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: derives this from his smiling father, as I should suspect, or
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: from his mother, it bodes evil for the poor girl who is in their
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: power."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I am sure that you are right, Mr. Holmes," cried our client. "A
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: thousand things come back to me which make me certain that you
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: have hit it. Oh, let us lose not an instant in bringing help to
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: this poor creature."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "We must be circumspect, for we are dealing with a very cunning
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: man. We can do nothing until seven o'clock. At that hour we shall
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: be with you, and it will not be long before we solve the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: mystery."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: We were as good as our word, for it was just seven when we
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: reached the Copper Beeches, having put up our trap at a wayside
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: public-house. The group of trees, with their dark leaves shining
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: like burnished metal in the light of the setting sun, were
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: sufficient to mark the house even had Miss Hunter not been
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: standing smiling on the door-step.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Have you managed it?" asked Holmes.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: A loud thudding noise came from somewhere downstairs. "That is
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: on the kitchen rug. Here are his keys, which are the duplicates
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: of Mr. Rucastle's."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "You have done well indeed!" cried Holmes with enthusiasm. "Now
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: lead the way, and we shall soon see the end of this black
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: business."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: We passed up the stair, unlocked the door, followed on down a
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: transverse bar. Then he tried the various keys in the lock, but
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: without success. No sound came from within, and at the silence
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Holmes' face clouded over.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "I trust that we are not too late," said he. "I think, Miss
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: your shoulder to it, and we shall see whether we cannot make our
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: way in."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: It was an old rickety door and gave at once before our united
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: strength. Together we rushed into the room. It was empty. There
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: gone.
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "There has been some villainy here," said Holmes; "this beauty
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: has guessed Miss Hunter's intentions and has carried his victim
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: off."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "But how?"
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "Through the skylight. We shall soon see how he managed it." He
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: swung himself up onto the roof. "Ah, yes," he cried, "here's the
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: end of a long light ladder against the eaves. That is how he did
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: it."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: there when the Rucastles went away."
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: "He has come back and done it. I tell you that he is a clever and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: fed for two days. Quick, quick, or it'll be too late!"
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Holmes and I rushed out and round the angle of the house, with
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: Toller hurrying behind us. There was the huge famished brute, its
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: black muzzle buried in Rucastle's throat, while he writhed and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: screamed upon the ground. Running up, I blew its brains out, and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: it fell over with its keen white teeth still meeting in the great
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: creases of his neck. With much labour we separated them and
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES

text: carried him, living but horribly mangled, into the house. We laid
story: XII. THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES
